options.value: Any Questions? A Guide to Asking HOT Questions
options.name: title_text

string.Text: Closed captions. Press the spacebar to toggle captions on and off.
Skip navigation. Press enter to return to the slide.

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

slidetranscripts.Text:
Welcome to this presentation on asking HOT questions.

Click next to continue.

We’ve all seen it, maybe we’ve even done it.

We ask students “Are there any questions? “Does everyone understand?” “Everybody get that?” and students look at us like this; like deer in the headlights.

They just want the teacher to move on. They don’t want to look stupid in front of their classmates.

Instead of asking these dead-end questions, we need to ask students questions that test their knowledge of the concepts.

In this presentation, we will learn how to ask HOT questions. But what is a HOT questions?

Click next to find out.

Benjamin Bloom’s Taxonomy of Learning comprises six levels of thinking that contribute to the learning process.

These levels of learning are often arranged in a pyramid of learning.

At the bottom of this pyramid are the lower order thinking skills, which include remembering, understanding, and applying.

At the top, are the higher order thinking skills, or HOT skills, which include analyzing, evaluating, and creating.

Our goal is to ask questions that reach the top portion of this pyramid and encourage students to think critically instead of asking questions with yes or no answers.

Click next to continue.

Complete the learning pyramid by typing in the levels of Bloom’s Taxonomy in the text boxes.

Then click submit to check your answer.

Drag and drop the verbs to the correct levels of Bloom’s Taxonomy.

Then click submit to check your answer.

Hover over the levels to view verbs associated with each.

Then click next.

Drag and drop the verbs to the correct levels of Bloom’s Taxonomy.

Then click submit to check your answer.

Hover over the levels to view question stems for each.

Then click next.

Drag and drop the levels of Bloom’s Taxonomy to the appropriate question.

Then click submit to check your answer.

Use the Google Doc to create your own HOT questions using the question stems and verbs.

Then try to identify the level of your peers’ questions and provide feedback using the commenting feature.

Finally, scroll down to the bottom and create a new page. Write a short paragraph outlining a plan describing how you can implement HOT questions into your next class.

Then click next to continue.

Thank you for completing this presentation.

If you have any questions, contact instructional designer Mike Stein.

Click Exit to exit this presentation.
